trans-unit.source: Scaling using the Elastic Database split-merge tool
trans-unit.target: Scaling using the Elastic Database split-merge tool

trans-unit.source: If you choose not to use the simple model of allocating separate databases for each shardlet (tenant), your application may need to flexibly redistribute data among databases when capacity needs fluctuate.
trans-unit.target: If you choose not to use the simple model of allocating separate databases for each shardlet (tenant), your application may need to flexibly redistribute data among databases when capacity needs fluctuate.

trans-unit.source: Elastic database tools includes a customer-hosted split-merge tool for rebalancing the data distribution and managing hotspots for sharded applications.
trans-unit.target: Elastic database tools includes a customer-hosted split-merge tool for rebalancing the data distribution and managing hotspots for sharded applications.

trans-unit.source: It builds on an underlying capability for moving shardlets on demand between different databases and integrates with shard map management to maintain consistent mappings.
trans-unit.target: It builds on an underlying capability for moving shardlets on demand between different databases and integrates with shard map management to maintain consistent mappings.

trans-unit.source: The split-merge tool manages scale-in and scale-out; you can add or remove databases from your shard set and use the split-merge tool to rebalance the distribution of shardlets among them.
trans-unit.target: The split-merge tool manages scale-in and scale-out; you can add or remove databases from your shard set and use the split-merge tool to rebalance the distribution of shardlets among them.

trans-unit.source: To upgrade to the latest version of split-merge, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To upgrade to the latest version of split-merge, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Download the latest version of the split-merge package from NuGet as described in <link><linkText>Download the split-merge packages</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Change your cloud service configuration file for your split-merge deployment to reflect the new configuration parameters.
trans-unit.target: Change your cloud service configuration file for your split-merge deployment to reflect the new configuration parameters.

trans-unit.source: A new required parameter is the information about the certificate used for encryption.
trans-unit.target: A new required parameter is the information about the certificate used for encryption.

trans-unit.source: An easy way to do this is to compare the new configuration template file from the download against your existing configuration.
trans-unit.target: An easy way to do this is to compare the new configuration template file from the download against your existing configuration.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you add the settings for “DataEncryptionPrimaryCertificateThumbprint” and “DataEncryptionPrimary” for both the web and the worker role.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you add the settings for “DataEncryptionPrimaryCertificateThumbprint” and “DataEncryptionPrimary” for both the web and the worker role.

trans-unit.source: Before deploying the update to Azure, ensure that all currently running split-merge operations have finished.
trans-unit.target: Before deploying the update to Azure, ensure that all currently running split-merge operations have finished.

trans-unit.source: You can easily do this by querying the RequestStatus and PendingWorkflows tables in the split-merge metadata database for ongoing requests.
trans-unit.target: You can easily do this by querying the RequestStatus and PendingWorkflows tables in the split-merge metadata database for ongoing requests.

trans-unit.source: Update your existing cloud service deployment for split-merge in your Azure subscription with the new package and your updated service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Update your existing cloud service deployment for split-merge in your Azure subscription with the new package and your updated service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to provision a new metadata database for split-merge to upgrade.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to provision a new metadata database for split-merge to upgrade.

trans-unit.source: The new version will automatically upgrade your existing metadata database to the new version.
trans-unit.target: The new version will automatically upgrade your existing metadata database to the new version.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios for split-merge
trans-unit.target: Scenarios for split-merge

trans-unit.source: Applications need to stretch flexibly beyond the limits of a single Azure SQL DB database, as illustrated by the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Applications need to stretch flexibly beyond the limits of a single Azure SQL DB database, as illustrated by the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Grow Capacity – Splitting Ranges: The ability to grow aggregate capacity at the data tier addresses increasing capacity needs.
trans-unit.target: Grow Capacity – Splitting Ranges: The ability to grow aggregate capacity at the data tier addresses increasing capacity needs.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, the application provides the additional capacity by sharding the data and by distributing it across incrementally more databases until capacity needs are fulfilled.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, the application provides the additional capacity by sharding the data and by distributing it across incrementally more databases until capacity needs are fulfilled.

trans-unit.source: The ‘split’ feature of the Elastic Scale split-merge Service addresses this scenario.
trans-unit.target: The ‘split’ feature of the Elastic Scale split-merge Service addresses this scenario.

trans-unit.source: Shrink Capacity – Merging Ranges: Capacity fluctuates due to the seasonal nature of a business.
trans-unit.target: Shrink Capacity – Merging Ranges: Capacity fluctuates due to the seasonal nature of a business.

trans-unit.source: This scenario underlines the need to easily scale back to fewer scale units when business slows.
trans-unit.target: This scenario underlines the need to easily scale back to fewer scale units when business slows.

trans-unit.source: The ‘merge’ feature in the Elastic Scale split-merge Service covers this requirement.
trans-unit.target: The ‘merge’ feature in the Elastic Scale split-merge Service covers this requirement.

trans-unit.source: Manage Hotspots – Moving Shardlets: With multiple tenants per database, the allocation of shardlets to shards can lead to capacity bottlenecks on some shards.
trans-unit.target: Manage Hotspots – Moving Shardlets: With multiple tenants per database, the allocation of shardlets to shards can lead to capacity bottlenecks on some shards.

trans-unit.source: This requires re-allocating shardlets or moving busy shardlets to new or less utilized shards.
trans-unit.target: This requires re-allocating shardlets or moving busy shardlets to new or less utilized shards.

trans-unit.source: In the following, we will refer to any processing in the service along these capabilities as split/merge/move requests.
trans-unit.target: In the following, we will refer to any processing in the service along these capabilities as split/merge/move requests.

trans-unit.source: Concepts & Key Features
trans-unit.target: Concepts & Key Features

trans-unit.source: Customer-Hosted Services: The split-merge is delivered as a customer-hosted service.
trans-unit.target: Customer-Hosted Services: The split-merge is delivered as a customer-hosted service.

trans-unit.source: You must deploy and host the service in your Microsoft Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You must deploy and host the service in your Microsoft Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: The package you download from NuGet contains a configuration template to complete with the information for your specific deployment.
trans-unit.target: The package you download from NuGet contains a configuration template to complete with the information for your specific deployment.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>split-merge tutorial</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>split-merge tutorial</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: Since the service runs in your Azure subscription, you can control and configure most security aspects of the service.
trans-unit.target: Since the service runs in your Azure subscription, you can control and configure most security aspects of the service.

trans-unit.source: The default template includes the options to configure SSL, certificate-based client authentication, encryption for stored credentials, DoS guarding and IP restrictions.
trans-unit.target: The default template includes the options to configure SSL, certificate-based client authentication, encryption for stored credentials, DoS guarding and IP restrictions.

trans-unit.source: You can find more information on the security aspects in the following document <link><linkText>split-merge security configuration</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find more information on the security aspects in the following document <link><linkText>split-merge security configuration</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The default deployed service runs with one worker and one web role.
trans-unit.target: The default deployed service runs with one worker and one web role.

trans-unit.source: Each uses the A1 VM size in Azure Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Each uses the A1 VM size in Azure Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: While you cannot modify these settings when deploying the package, you could change them after a successful deployment in the running cloud service, (through the Azure portal).
trans-unit.target: While you cannot modify these settings when deploying the package, you could change them after a successful deployment in the running cloud service, (through the Azure portal).

trans-unit.source: Note that the worker role must not be configured for more than a single instance for technical reasons.
trans-unit.target: Note that the worker role must not be configured for more than a single instance for technical reasons.

trans-unit.source: Shard Map Integration: The split-merge service interacts with the shard map of the application.
trans-unit.target: Shard Map Integration: The split-merge service interacts with the shard map of the application.

trans-unit.source: When using the split-merge service to split or merge ranges or to move shardlets between shards, the service automatically keeps the shard map up to date.
trans-unit.target: When using the split-merge service to split or merge ranges or to move shardlets between shards, the service automatically keeps the shard map up to date.

trans-unit.source: To do so, the service connects to the shard map manager database of the application and maintains ranges and mappings as split/merge/move requests progress.
trans-unit.target: To do so, the service connects to the shard map manager database of the application and maintains ranges and mappings as split/merge/move requests progress.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that the shard map always presents an up-to-date view when split-merge operations are going on.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that the shard map always presents an up-to-date view when split-merge operations are going on.

trans-unit.source: Split, merge and shardlet movement operations are implemented by moving a batch of shardlets from the source shard to the target shard.
trans-unit.target: Split, merge and shardlet movement operations are implemented by moving a batch of shardlets from the source shard to the target shard.

trans-unit.source: During the shardlet movement operation the shardlets subject to the current batch are marked as offline in the shard map and are unavailable for data-dependent routing connections using the OpenConnectionForKey API.
trans-unit.target: During the shardlet movement operation the shardlets subject to the current batch are marked as offline in the shard map and are unavailable for data-dependent routing connections using the OpenConnectionForKey API.

trans-unit.source: Consistent Shardlet Connections: When data movement starts for a new batch of shardlets, any shard-map provided data-dependent routing connections to the shard storing the shardlet are killed and subsequent connections from the shard map APIs to the these shardlets are blocked while the data movement is in progress in order to avoid inconsistencies.
trans-unit.target: Consistent Shardlet Connections: When data movement starts for a new batch of shardlets, any shard-map provided data-dependent routing connections to the shard storing the shardlet are killed and subsequent connections from the shard map APIs to the these shardlets are blocked while the data movement is in progress in order to avoid inconsistencies.

trans-unit.source: Connections to other shardlets on the same shard will also get killed, but will succeed again immediately on retry.
trans-unit.target: Connections to other shardlets on the same shard will also get killed, but will succeed again immediately on retry.

trans-unit.source: Once the batch is moved, the shardlets are marked online again for the target shard and the source data is removed from the source shard.
trans-unit.target: Once the batch is moved, the shardlets are marked online again for the target shard and the source data is removed from the source shard.

trans-unit.source: The service goes through these steps for every batch until all shardlets have been moved.
trans-unit.target: The service goes through these steps for every batch until all shardlets have been moved.

trans-unit.source: This will lead to several connection kill operations during the course of the complete split/merge/move operation.
trans-unit.target: This will lead to several connection kill operations during the course of the complete split/merge/move operation.

trans-unit.source: Managing Shardlet Availability: Limiting the connection killing to the current batch of shardlets as discussed above restricts the scope of unavailability to one batch of shardlets at a time.
trans-unit.target: Managing Shardlet Availability: Limiting the connection killing to the current batch of shardlets as discussed above restricts the scope of unavailability to one batch of shardlets at a time.

trans-unit.source: This is preferred over an approach where the complete shard would remain offline for all its shardlets during the course of a split or merge operation.
trans-unit.target: This is preferred over an approach where the complete shard would remain offline for all its shardlets during the course of a split or merge operation.

trans-unit.source: The size of a batch, defined as the number of distinct shardlets to move at a time, is a configuration parameter.
trans-unit.target: The size of a batch, defined as the number of distinct shardlets to move at a time, is a configuration parameter.

trans-unit.source: It can be defined for each split and merge operation depending on the application’s availability and performance needs.
trans-unit.target: It can be defined for each split and merge operation depending on the application’s availability and performance needs.

trans-unit.source: Note that the range that is being locked in the shard map may be larger than the batch size specified.
trans-unit.target: Note that the range that is being locked in the shard map may be larger than the batch size specified.

trans-unit.source: This is because the service picks the range size such that the actual number of sharding key values in the data approximately matches the batch size.
trans-unit.target: This is because the service picks the range size such that the actual number of sharding key values in the data approximately matches the batch size.

trans-unit.source: This is important to remember in particular for sparsely populated sharding keys.
trans-unit.target: This is important to remember in particular for sparsely populated sharding keys.

trans-unit.source: Metadata Storage: The split-merge service uses a database to maintain its status and to keep logs during request processing.
trans-unit.target: Metadata Storage: The split-merge service uses a database to maintain its status and to keep logs during request processing.

trans-unit.source: The user creates this database in their subscription and provides the connection string for it in the configuration file for the service deployment.
trans-unit.target: The user creates this database in their subscription and provides the connection string for it in the configuration file for the service deployment.

trans-unit.source: Administrators from the user’s organization can also connect to this database to review request progress and to investigate detailed information regarding potential failures.
trans-unit.target: Administrators from the user’s organization can also connect to this database to review request progress and to investigate detailed information regarding potential failures.

trans-unit.source: Sharding-Awareness: The split-merge service differentiates between (1) sharded tables, (2) reference tables, and (3) normal tables.
trans-unit.target: Sharding-Awareness: The split-merge service differentiates between (1) sharded tables, (2) reference tables, and (3) normal tables.

trans-unit.source: The semantics of a split/merge/move operation depend on the type of the table used and are defined as follows:
trans-unit.target: The semantics of a split/merge/move operation depend on the type of the table used and are defined as follows:

trans-unit.source: Sharded tables: Split, merge, and move operations move shardlets from source to target shard.
trans-unit.target: Sharded tables: Split, merge, and move operations move shardlets from source to target shard.

trans-unit.source: After successful completion of the overall request, those shardlets are no longer present on the source.
trans-unit.target: After successful completion of the overall request, those shardlets are no longer present on the source.

trans-unit.source: Note that the target tables need to exist on the target shard and must not contain data in the target range prior to processing of the operation.
trans-unit.target: Note that the target tables need to exist on the target shard and must not contain data in the target range prior to processing of the operation.

trans-unit.source: Reference tables: For reference tables, the split, merge and move operations copy the data from the source to the target shard.
trans-unit.target: Reference tables: For reference tables, the split, merge and move operations copy the data from the source to the target shard.

trans-unit.source: Note, however, that no changes occur on the target shard for a given table if any row is already present in this table on the target.
trans-unit.target: Note, however, that no changes occur on the target shard for a given table if any row is already present in this table on the target.

trans-unit.source: The table has to be empty for any reference table copy operation to get processed.
trans-unit.target: The table has to be empty for any reference table copy operation to get processed.

trans-unit.source: Other Tables: Other tables can be present on either the source or the target of a split and merge operation.
trans-unit.target: Other Tables: Other tables can be present on either the source or the target of a split and merge operation.

trans-unit.source: The split-merge service disregards these tables for any data movement or copy operations.
trans-unit.target: The split-merge service disregards these tables for any data movement or copy operations.

trans-unit.source: Note, however, that they can interfere with these operations in case of constraints.
trans-unit.target: Note, however, that they can interfere with these operations in case of constraints.

trans-unit.source: The information on reference vs. sharded tables is provided by the SchemaInfo APIs on the shard map.
trans-unit.target: The information on reference vs. sharded tables is provided by the SchemaInfo APIs on the shard map.

trans-unit.source: The following example illustrates the use of these APIs on a given shard map manager object smm:
trans-unit.target: The following example illustrates the use of these APIs on a given shard map manager object smm:

trans-unit.source: The tables ‘region’ and ‘nation’ are defined as reference tables and will be copied with split/merge/move operations.
trans-unit.target: The tables ‘region’ and ‘nation’ are defined as reference tables and will be copied with split/merge/move operations.

trans-unit.source: ‘customer’ and ‘orders’ in turn are defined as sharded tables.
trans-unit.target: ‘customer’ and ‘orders’ in turn are defined as sharded tables.

trans-unit.source: C_CUSTKEY and O_CUSTKEY serve as the sharding key.
trans-unit.target: C_CUSTKEY and O_CUSTKEY serve as the sharding key.

trans-unit.source: Referential Integrity: The split-merge service analyzes dependencies between tables and uses foreign key-primary key relationships to stage the operations for moving reference tables and shardlets.
trans-unit.target: Referential Integrity: The split-merge service analyzes dependencies between tables and uses foreign key-primary key relationships to stage the operations for moving reference tables and shardlets.

trans-unit.source: In general, reference tables are copied first in dependency order, then shardlets are copied in order of their dependencies within each batch.
trans-unit.target: In general, reference tables are copied first in dependency order, then shardlets are copied in order of their dependencies within each batch.

trans-unit.source: This is necessary so that FK-PK constraints on the target shard are honored as the new data arrives.
trans-unit.target: This is necessary so that FK-PK constraints on the target shard are honored as the new data arrives.

trans-unit.source: Shard Map Consistency and Eventual Completion: In the presence of failures, the split-merge service resumes operations after any outage and aims to complete any in progress requests.
trans-unit.target: Shard Map Consistency and Eventual Completion: In the presence of failures, the split-merge service resumes operations after any outage and aims to complete any in progress requests.

trans-unit.source: However, there may be unrecoverable situations, e.g., when the target shard is lost or compromised beyond repair.
trans-unit.target: However, there may be unrecoverable situations, e.g., when the target shard is lost or compromised beyond repair.

trans-unit.source: Under those circumstances, some shardlets that were supposed to be moved may continue to reside on the source shard.
trans-unit.target: Under those circumstances, some shardlets that were supposed to be moved may continue to reside on the source shard.

trans-unit.source: The service ensures that shardlet mappings are only updated after the necessary data has been successfully copied to the target.
trans-unit.target: The service ensures that shardlet mappings are only updated after the necessary data has been successfully copied to the target.

trans-unit.source: Shardlets are only deleted on the source once all their data has been copied to the target and the corresponding mappings have been updated successfully.
trans-unit.target: Shardlets are only deleted on the source once all their data has been copied to the target and the corresponding mappings have been updated successfully.

trans-unit.source: The deletion operation happens in the background while the range is already online on the target shard.
trans-unit.target: The deletion operation happens in the background while the range is already online on the target shard.

trans-unit.source: The split-merge service always ensures correctness of the mappings stored in the shard map.
trans-unit.target: The split-merge service always ensures correctness of the mappings stored in the shard map.

trans-unit.source: Requirements and Limitations
trans-unit.target: Requirements and Limitations

trans-unit.source: The current implementation of the split-merge service is subject to the following requirements and limitations:
trans-unit.target: The current implementation of the split-merge service is subject to the following requirements and limitations:

trans-unit.source: Currently, the shards need to exist and be registered in the shard map before a split-merge operation on these shards can be performed.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the shards need to exist and be registered in the shard map before a split-merge operation on these shards can be performed.

trans-unit.source: The split-merge service currently does not create tables or any other database objects automatically as part of its operations.
trans-unit.target: The split-merge service currently does not create tables or any other database objects automatically as part of its operations.

trans-unit.source: This means that the schema for all sharded tables and reference tables need to exist on the target shard prior to any split/merge/move operation.
trans-unit.target: This means that the schema for all sharded tables and reference tables need to exist on the target shard prior to any split/merge/move operation.

trans-unit.source: Sharded tables in particular are required to be empty in the range where new shardlets are to be added by a split/merge/move operation.
trans-unit.target: Sharded tables in particular are required to be empty in the range where new shardlets are to be added by a split/merge/move operation.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the operation will fail the initial consistency check on the target shard.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the operation will fail the initial consistency check on the target shard.

trans-unit.source: Also note that reference data is only copied if the reference table is empty and that there are no consistency guarantees with regard to other concurrent write operations on the reference tables.
trans-unit.target: Also note that reference data is only copied if the reference table is empty and that there are no consistency guarantees with regard to other concurrent write operations on the reference tables.

trans-unit.source: We recommend this: when running split/merge operations, no other write operations make changes to the reference tables.
trans-unit.target: We recommend this: when running split/merge operations, no other write operations make changes to the reference tables.

trans-unit.source: The service currently relies on row identity established by a unique index or key that includes the sharding key to improve performance and reliability for large shardlets.
trans-unit.target: The service currently relies on row identity established by a unique index or key that includes the sharding key to improve performance and reliability for large shardlets.

trans-unit.source: This allows the service to move data at an even finer granularity than just the sharding key value.
trans-unit.target: This allows the service to move data at an even finer granularity than just the sharding key value.

trans-unit.source: This helps to reduce the maximum amount of log space and locks that are required during the operation.
trans-unit.target: This helps to reduce the maximum amount of log space and locks that are required during the operation.

trans-unit.source: Consider creating a unique index or a primary key including the sharding key on a given table if you want to use that table with split/merge/move requests.
trans-unit.target: Consider creating a unique index or a primary key including the sharding key on a given table if you want to use that table with split/merge/move requests.

trans-unit.source: For performance reasons, the sharding key should be the leading column in the key or the index.
trans-unit.target: For performance reasons, the sharding key should be the leading column in the key or the index.

trans-unit.source: During the course of request processing, some shardlet data may be present both on the source and the target shard.
trans-unit.target: During the course of request processing, some shardlet data may be present both on the source and the target shard.

trans-unit.source: This is currently necessary to protect against failures during the shardlet movement.
trans-unit.target: This is currently necessary to protect against failures during the shardlet movement.

trans-unit.source: As explained above, the integration of split-merge with the Elastic Scale shard map ensures, that connections through the data dependent routing APIs using the OpenConnectionForKey method on the shard map do not see any inconsistent intermediate states.
trans-unit.target: As explained above, the integration of split-merge with the Elastic Scale shard map ensures, that connections through the data dependent routing APIs using the OpenConnectionForKey method on the shard map do not see any inconsistent intermediate states.

trans-unit.source: However, when connecting to the source or the target shards without using the OpenConnectionForKey method, inconsistent intermediate states might be visible when split/merge/move requests are going on.
trans-unit.target: However, when connecting to the source or the target shards without using the OpenConnectionForKey method, inconsistent intermediate states might be visible when split/merge/move requests are going on.

trans-unit.source: These connections may show partial or duplicate results depending on the timing or the shard underlying the connection.
trans-unit.target: These connections may show partial or duplicate results depending on the timing or the shard underlying the connection.

trans-unit.source: This limitation currently includes the connections made by Elastic Scale Multi-Shard-Queries.
trans-unit.target: This limitation currently includes the connections made by Elastic Scale Multi-Shard-Queries.

trans-unit.source: The metadata database for the split-merge service must not be shared between different roles.
trans-unit.target: The metadata database for the split-merge service must not be shared between different roles.

trans-unit.source: For example, a role of the split-merge service running in staging needs to point to a different metadata database than the production role.

trans-unit.source: Billing

trans-unit.source: The split-merge service runs as a cloud service in your Microsoft Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The split-merge service runs as a cloud service in your Microsoft Azure subscription.

trans-unit.target: Therefore charges for cloud services apply to your instance of the service.

trans-unit.source: Status Tables
trans-unit.target: Status Tables

trans-unit.source: The split-merge Service provides the RequestStatus table in the metadata store database for monitoring of completed and ongoing requests.
trans-unit.target: The split-merge Service provides the RequestStatus table in the metadata store database for monitoring of completed and ongoing requests.

trans-unit.source: The table lists a row for each split-merge request that has been submitted to this instance of the split-merge service.
trans-unit.target: The table lists a row for each split-merge request that has been submitted to this instance of the split-merge service.

trans-unit.source: It gives the following information for each request:
trans-unit.target: It gives the following information for each request:

trans-unit.source: Timestamp: The time and date when the request was started.
trans-unit.target: Timestamp: The time and date when the request was started.

trans-unit.source: OperationId: A GUID that uniquely identifies the request.
trans-unit.target: OperationId: A GUID that uniquely identifies the request.

trans-unit.source: This request can also be used to cancel the operation while it is still ongoing.
trans-unit.target: This request can also be used to cancel the operation while it is still ongoing.

trans-unit.source: Status: The current state of the request.
trans-unit.target: Status: The current state of the request.

trans-unit.source: For ongoing requests, it also lists the current phase in which the request is.
trans-unit.target: For ongoing requests, it also lists the current phase in which the request is.

trans-unit.source: CancelRequest: A flag that indicates whether the request has been cancelled.
trans-unit.target: CancelRequest: A flag that indicates whether the request has been cancelled.

trans-unit.source: Progress: A percentage estimate of completion for the operation.
trans-unit.target: Progress: A percentage estimate of completion for the operation.

trans-unit.source: A value of 50 indicates that the operation is approximately 50% complete.
trans-unit.target: A value of 50 indicates that the operation is approximately 50% complete.

trans-unit.source: Details: An XML value that provides a more detailed progress report.
trans-unit.target: Details: An XML value that provides a more detailed progress report.

trans-unit.source: The progress report is periodically updated as sets of rows are copied from source to target.
trans-unit.target: The progress report is periodically updated as sets of rows are copied from source to target.

trans-unit.source: In case of failures or exceptions, this column also includes more detailed information about the failure.
trans-unit.target: In case of failures or exceptions, this column also includes more detailed information about the failure.

trans-unit.source: Performance
trans-unit.target: Performance

trans-unit.source: In general, better performance is to be expected from the higher, more performant service tiers in Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: In general, better performance is to be expected from the higher, more performant service tiers in Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Higher IO, CPU and memory allocations for the higher service tiers benefit the bulk copy and delete operations that the split-merge service uses.
trans-unit.target: Higher IO, CPU and memory allocations for the higher service tiers benefit the bulk copy and delete operations that the split-merge service uses.

trans-unit.source: For that reason, increase the service tier just for those databases for a defined, limited period of time.
trans-unit.target: For that reason, increase the service tier just for those databases for a defined, limited period of time.

trans-unit.source: The service also performs validation queries as part of its normal operations.
trans-unit.target: The service also performs validation queries as part of its normal operations.

trans-unit.source: These validation queries check for unexpected presence of data in the target range and ensure that any split/merge/move operation starts from a consistent state.
trans-unit.target: These validation queries check for unexpected presence of data in the target range and ensure that any split/merge/move operation starts from a consistent state.

trans-unit.source: These queries all work over sharding key ranges defined by the scope of the operation and the batch size provided as part of the request definition.
trans-unit.target: These queries all work over sharding key ranges defined by the scope of the operation and the batch size provided as part of the request definition.

trans-unit.source: These queries perform best when an index is present that has the sharding key as the leading column.
trans-unit.target: These queries perform best when an index is present that has the sharding key as the leading column.

trans-unit.source: In addition, a uniqueness property with the sharding key as the leading column will allow the service to use an optimized approach that limits resource consumption in terms of log space and memory.
trans-unit.target: In addition, a uniqueness property with the sharding key as the leading column will allow the service to use an optimized approach that limits resource consumption in terms of log space and memory.

trans-unit.source: This uniqueness property is required to move large data sizes (typically above 1GB).
trans-unit.target: This uniqueness property is required to move large data sizes (typically above 1GB).
